executive_summary:
Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2024 currency.

The Homeowners' Associations industry comprises housing management organizations that deliver governance, community and business services to their residents. This industry also includes, to a lesser extent, regulatory athletic associations and sports governing bodies. Over the past five years, industry revenue will grow at a CAGR of 0.2% to $38.2 billion, including a 0.2% growth in 2024 alone. Industry revenue has benefited from growth in per capita disposable income, memberships and the number of housing starts.

Most industry enterprises are structured as nonprofit organizations that reinvest any earned profit into the community. Homeowners' Associations industry organizations typically only generate enough revenue to cover required maintenance, community programs and reserve funding. The majority of industry revenue is generated through assessment fees that residents pay to the association. As a result, revenue growth is primarily driven by increased members, although homeowners' associations will occasionally increase required assessments, if necessary, to cover costs.

Over the next five years, industry revenue will rise at a CAGR of 1.7% to $41.6 billion. The industry will be negatively affected by a slight decline in the homeownership rate, with a portion of new homeowners anticipated to be part of homeowners' associations. Nonetheless, community associations will gain members as more people consider homeowners' associations efficient providers of community services and a way to foster a close sense of community. Furthermore, the industry will receive a boost as the baby boomer generation enters retirement. Community associations are popular among seniors due to the variety of leisure activities and social events that they provide. A gradual employment recovery and consistent disposable income growth will also help drive industry revenue growth over the next five years.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: An estimated 74.1 million Americans live in association-governed communities, according to the Community Association Institute (CAI) in 2020 (latest data available). Homeowners' associations are designed to protect home values and provide amenities such as swimming pools, tennis courts, playgrounds and security services for their communities. While memberships rose, the number of industry establishments declined, suggesting a simultaneous decrease in the number of associations but an increase in their average size, measured by total membership.

Homeowner and community associations garner revenue through membership assessment payments, which make up the vast majority of revenue and are used to cover the operational cost of the association. Revenue maturing is driven by an increase in the number of association members than annual increases in assessment rates. According to 2020 data from CAI, 78.0% of all new housing built for sale is part of a community association. Given that most completed new single-family housing units are part of homeowners' associations, an increase in the overall number of housing starts helps drive growth in membership for the industry.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: HOMEOWNERS' ASSOCIATIONS HAVE GROWN IN POPULARITY
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Increasingly, counties and municipalities are delegating their service provision obligations by requiring that developers of residential properties create homeowners' associations to fulfill such tasks.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: While many homeowners' associations include rental properties in their communities, single-family houses typically constitute the majority of residential units. Despite an expected marginal drop in the homeownership rate, per capita disposable income growth will drive communities that homeowners' associations manage, thereby growing membership.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: An uptick in the number of housing starts throughout the outlook period is also expected to drive revenue growth for homeowner associations
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As more houses will be built, more members can potentially enter a homeowner's association and begin to pay dues.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Growing Popularity of Industry Associations Will Continue to Drive Growth in Membership
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: US community associations, which include planned communities, condominium communities and housing cooperatives, will remain popular because they ensure collective management and protect housing values and equity. Planned communities are attracting new members by providing an increasingly diverse range of community involvement events, including large-scale community events for special holidays, social interest clubs and opportunities for recreation. Homeowners' associations will remain popular among condominium owners to manage building exteriors and shared spaces.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Senior Living Communities Will Be the New Revenue Driver
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: In particular, homeowners' associations and living communities restricted to seniors will become more popular, contributing to overall growth in association membership. According to data from the Foundation for Community Association Research, 5.1% of persons over the age of 55 currently live in condominiums and 14.1% of all homeowners' associations comprise age-restricted communities. Due to their increasing popularity and the growing baby boomer population, membership in such communities will increase. Homeowners' and other community associations are attractive to this age bracket because they provide a variety of leisure activities and social events for their members.

Social media and technology will continue to provide organizations with tools to connect members, give them more ways to access amenities, pay membership dues and interact more with the homeowners association. Fatigue from social isolation and other conditions associated with the pandemic have spurred consumers to get more involved in social activities. This newfound source of demand could offset some of the wider trends of diminishing membership for industry associations.

industry_definition: This industry primarily consists of homeowners' associations. A homeowners' association is a legal entity created for the purpose of developing, managing, selling or administering a community of homes. It is given the authority to enforce the community's covenants, conditions and restrictions, and to manage its common amenities. This industry also consists of regulatory athletic associations, sports governing bodies and sports leagues (regulating bodies).
key_trends: The industry has benefited overall from increased association residents and per capita disposable income growth. In 2022, though, revenue declined due to a decline in per capita disposable income and its associated economic consequences.

The industry will benefit from the increasing public acceptance of community associations as efficient providers of services and a means to create vibrant communities. But the housing market will cool down due to climbing interest rates.

The association's primary purpose is to protect and preserve the value of privately and commonly used property. The association may be responsible for repairing and maintaining portions of the community, such as roads, roofs and recreation facilities.

Although most industry associations are nonprofit corporations under state laws, they're not nonprofit under federal income tax laws, so they're not tax-exempt. Therefore, only some homeowners receive government assistance in this way.

A large portion of revenue is generated through these organizations' assessment fees. Using this revenue, homeowners' associations provide the following core services to their residents: governance, community services and business services.

The industry primarily consists of homeowner's associations, condominium associations, cooperatives and property owners' associations. To a lesser extent, the industry also consists of regulatory sports bodies and other membership organizations that generate revenue through other means.
Organizations in the industry, which includes sport governing bodies and homeowners' associations, are primarily concentrated in the Mid-Atlantic, Southeast and Western parts of the United States.
At the state level, most homeowners' associations are located in New York, Florida and California. Other notable states by the number of industry establishments include Illinois and Hawaii.
Due to the local scope of operations for many organizations in this industry, the market share concentration level is low.
Acquiring skilled labor doesn't pose a significant barrier to entry, as it's possible to provide industry services to residents using volunteer labor consisting of community members and residents.
The industry mainly comprises small, regional companies that don't control more than 5.0% of the market share.

The size of certain cost components may vary significantly between homeowners' associations, depending on their size and service programming. On average, the most significant cost components in this industry are wages and utility costs.
Homeowners' Associations (HOAs) are typically responsible for paying basic utilities, such as water and gas. Some might even cover the cost of municipal services, such as trash, sewer and recycling.

When the real estate market is strong and individuals are purchasing more homes, membership in homeowners' associations rises. Higher membership levels lead to an increase in total assessment charges, representing an opportunity for the industry.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Residential communities typically have a mix of housing types and common association areas, including a clubhouse and recreational and maintenance facilities. Homeowners' associations for residential communities will often provide a range of community events and activities, including annual celebrations, special interest clubs and other events.

Combination resorts and residential communities are residential communities that also typically include golf courses, marinas, ski areas, hotels, timeshares and other amenities. Compared with strictly residential communities, resort and residential communities often have more part-time or seasonal residents. The primary difference between private club communities and combination resort and residential communities is that access to amenities is limited to members only.

These communities are also often called active adult or senior living communities. While age is not protected under the Fair Housing Act, the law prevents discrimination based on familial status. Under the Housing for Older Persons Act of 1995 (HOPA), however, senior living communities are exempt from liability for familial status discrimination. To qualify, a facility or community must prove that its housing is intended for senior occupants and must comply with regulatory requirements for the age verification of residents. On average, a higher portion of residents in age-restricted communities are part-time or seasonal residents.
The primary difference between private club communities and combination resort and residential communities is that access to amenities is limited to members only.

Mixed-use communities are residential communities with a significant public retail and commercial aspect, including, but limited to public retail or commercial space on the first floor with residential units above. Mixed-use communities encourage more walking, social interaction and a sense of urban living by decreasing the amount of sprawl, thereby increasing the density level. Mixed-use communities also often come with challenges due to differing interests and goals between residents and retail establishments.

products_and_services.product_description: These fees cover utility and maintenance services covered by homeowners' associations and other services such as regular social events and access to recreational facilities. In exchange for assessment fees, homeowners' associations provide business services, including maintaining buildings and community areas that protect the value of homes within the community. Within this segment, there are various types of associations. The largest is traditional homeowners' associations, followed by condominium communities and cooperatives. Regardless of the type of building or size of the community, all associations exist to provide the following core services: governance, community services and business services.

All other services are estimated to constitute 26.2% of total revenue. This segment includes revenue generated from membership services, rental of residential spaces, prepared meals and beverages and private contributions.

Licensing fees are revenue from selling licensing rights to use intellectual property protected by copyrights, trademarks, and broadcast rights. This type of revenue is particularly pertinent for regulatory athletic associations, such as the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the United States Olympic Committee. This segment experienced significant downward pressure due to canceling sporting events in 2020 but rebounded after events were allowed to resume.

Program service revenue can be broadly defined as revenue received by an organization charging for the services for which it received tax exemption. In the case of homeowners' associations, program service revenue might include any payment it receives for providing its services outside of normal assessment revenue such as renting out community space or selling tickets for a special event.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: When the real estate market is strong and individuals are purchasing more homes, membership in homeowners' associations rises. Higher membership levels lead to an increase in total assessment charges, representing an opportunity for the industry.
As more households generate higher income levels, they can afford membership in communities governed by homeowners' associations, driving revenue growth for the industry.
A decrease in the number of new housing units negatively affects membership in industry organizations, given that many tend to be governed by homeowners' associations.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Number of Adults Aged 50 and Older
demand_determinants.determinant_description: An increase in adults aged 50 and older, a large consumer market for the Homeowners' Associations industry, benefits industry revenue because this group has the per capita income necessary to belong to a community.

While condominiums and apartment cooperatives are common in urban areas, homeowners' associations for planned communities are typically located in undeveloped suburban areas. An increase in the urban population poses a threat to the industry.

business_locations.location_description: New York accounts for most of the region's total share. Given the area's population density and rental laws that have historically favored landlords, New York is home to many homeowners' associations, cooperatives and tenants' associations. The state's population density also favors a high number of sports leagues, which further increases the number of sports governing bodies in the state.

Florida accounts for a significant portion of establishments in the region. In this part of the country, new single-family housing units are more likely to be a part of a homeowners' association. According to the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), 67.0% of all new single-family houses completed in the south were part of a homeowners' association in 2019. That rate is higher compared to 62.0% at the national level, contributing to the area's high share of industry establishments.
The region has an ample amount of buildable land. California is one of the largest contributors to the region's concentration.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Currently, a broad range of codes governs activity in this industry, including general building codes, residential codes, mechanical codes, plumbing codes, electric codes, fire codes, accessibility codes, zoning codes, state codes, local codes and ordinances.
The Department of Housing and Development endorsed a new building code to ensure that new housing developments are accessible to people with disabilities.

basis_points.basis_description: Due to the local scope of operations for many organizations in this industry, the market share concentration level is low.
Acquiring skilled labor doesn't pose a significant barrier to entry, as it's possible to provide industry services to residents using volunteer labor consisting of community members and residents.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The combined revenue of the four most prominent organizations in the industry accounted for less than 10.0% of total revenue.

This industry also includes athletic regulatory organizations and sports supervising bodies, in which market share concentration is slightly higher because such organizations are more likely to operate at the national level.
Due to the industry's nature, associations are confined to operating within a local or regional scope.
The largest homeowners' associations, such as the Reston Association and the Highlands Ranch Community Association, have more than 50,000 residents in their communities.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases include contracted work for the common property's repair, replacement and enhancement.
As a service industry, wages typically constitute a significant share of industry revenue.
Most homeowner and community associations are organized as nonprofit organizations.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Capital is often limited to computers and other equipment
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Capital is often limited to computers and other equipment to produce newsletters and keep detailed membership and financial details.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low rate of new patents and concentration of patents
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Member assessments are the primary determinant of revenue volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: As the primary source of revenue for the industry, member assessments are the primary determinant of revenue volatility.

Changes in the number of member residents can also affect assessment revenue. Since homeownership is typically a long-term investment, the number of members does not tend to be volatile, contributing to significantly stable assessment revenue.

FAQs.question: Does your company partner with local businesses for mutually beneficial advertising?
FAQs.answer: Homeowners' associations oftentimes partner with local organizations to sponsor community events or programs.

FAQs.question: Is membership reliant on the overall health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: The majority of members in homeowners' associations are homeowners, rather than renters. Since owning a home is a relatively longer-term investment, membership in homeowners' associations does not fluctuate as closely with US macroeconomic trends.

FAQs.question: How does your company determine assessment rates?
FAQs.answer: The large majority of revenue for industry organizations is generated through member assessment fees, which may be required to paid monthly or annual depending on the community. In addition, some organizations might try and limit increases in the rate while others increase their rate often.

FAQs.question: Does your organization attempt to generate revenue through other sources of income?
FAQs.answer: The majority of organizations generate revenue through assessments, however revenue can come from other sources. For example, the Highlands Ranch Community Association charges for recreational day camp programs. Other sources of revenue might include rent from parking spaces or advertising.

FAQs.question: Does your company leverage social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter and Instagram to connect with community members?
FAQs.answer: Fostering community is a primary responsibility for homeowners associations. Social media offers a platform for members to connect and socialize. In addition, social media can function as way to keep a large member group informed and up-to-date on all important events and announcements.

FAQs.question: What software or technologies does your organization use to manage?
FAQs.answer: Technology use for homeowners' associations is pretty limited, consisting mainly of software used for internal processes and communication with the broader community.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations, like new energy-efficiency standards?
FAQs.answer: For the most part, industry organizations are not subject to high levels of regulation. Industry organizations, are nonprofit organizations and must adhere to the guidelines required of such a tax status. However, it is common for industry organizations to set their own standards that apply to all members.

FAQs.question: How does your organization handle non-compliance by members?
FAQs.answer: Industry organizations set rules and policies regarding noise levels, house appearance and assessment requirements. When members fail to comply with these, homeowners' associations are responsible for enforcing them, the methods by which differ between organizations.

FAQs.question: How often does your organization need to increase its assessment rate in order to cover planned operating expenses? How is this rate set?
FAQs.answer: This helps ensure that the homeowners' association, as a not-for-profit entity, always remains within its actual financial boundaries or resources.

FAQs.question: Is your organization affected by changes in the homeownership rate?
FAQs.answer: When the real estate market is strong and individuals are purchasing more homes, membership in homeowners' associations rises. Higher membership levels, in turn, leads to an increase in total assessment charges, which positively affects industry revenue.

FAQs.question: Is your homeowners' association located in an urban or suburban area? What are the challenges that come with operating in this environment?
FAQs.answer: While condominium and apartment cooperatives are common in urban areas, homeowners' associations for planned communities, which make up the bulk of industry organizations, are typically located in suburban areas that have not been already developed.

FAQs.question: What portion of your residents are low income? How many residents would you describe as upper middle class or upper class?
FAQs.answer: As more households generate higher levels of income, they will be able to afford membership in communities governed by homeowners' associations, driving revenue growth for the industry.
